FESI.Data
Class ESReference

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--FESI.Data.ESReference
public class ESReference
extends Object

Currently a reference is not a FESI value, as it can never be returned as a valid value by an EcmaScript function (8.7). It would be easy to make ESReference a subclass of ESValue or to create a common superclass (ESData) for both ESReference and ESValue if so desired in the future (in fact this was the case in the first version of the system).

References are less used than in the standard, as they are built only if required for assignement.

          Create a new reference given a base and a property name

Method Detail

getBase

public ESValue getBase()
                throws EcmaScriptException
Return the base object to which the property applies Only used for the DELETE operation. See 8.7.1
Returns:
The base object, possibly null
Throws:
EcmaScriptException - Not thrown

getPropertyName

public String getPropertyName()
                       throws EcmaScriptException
Get the name of the property to apply to the base object Only used for the DELETE operation. See 8.7.2
Returns:
The name of the property, never null
Throws:
EcmaScriptException - not thrown

getValue

public ESValue getValue()
                 throws EcmaScriptException
Return the referenced value unless it is global and not defined, in which case an exception is raised (see 8.7.3). By the definition of getProperty, and undefined value is returned if the base object is defined but the property does not exist (see 8.6.2.1).
Returns:
The referenced value
Throws:
EcmaScriptException - if the value is not defined

putValue

public void putValue(ESObject g,
                     ESValue v)
              throws EcmaScriptException
Update the referenced value, creating it if needed. If the base is is null use the global object, otherwise use the base object. See 8.7.4.
Parameters:
g - The global object to use if thre base is null
v - The value to put
Throws:
EcmaScriptException - May be thrown by putProperty

toDetailString

public String toDetailString()
Return a string identifying the reference type and its content
Returns:
a string

toString

public String toString()
Return the name of the reference, using a dot notation (could use the bracket notation, or check which one is most appropriate). Note that the base object is returned between braces, we do not know its name at this stage. This is used for debugging purpose, there is no way to get the string of a reference in EcmaScript.
Overrides:
toString in class Object
Returns:
The string naming the reference.
